Class SAWDatabaseHelper

  • java.lang.Object
    • SQLiteOpenHelper
      • SAWDatabaseHelper

  • public class SAWDatabaseHelper
extends SQLiteOpenHelper
    A class containing useful Database functions for the SAW (Software Alliance Wales) iBeacon hack.

    Example usage, assuming you have two databases in the /assets folder of your project:

    /assets/mydatabase.sqlite
    /assets/myotherdatabase.sqlite
      SAWDatabaseHelper dbOne = SAWDatabaseHelper.getInstance(getApplicationContext(), "mydatabase");
  SAWDatabaseHelper dbTwo = SAWDatabaseHelper.getInstance(getApplicationContext(), "myotherdatabase");
    After getting hold of the databases, queries map as follows:

    "SELECT column FROM table WHERE value=a"
     try {
 
        String result = dbOne.getStringWithQuery("table", "column", "value=?", new String[] { "a" } );
 } catch (DataNotFoundException dnfe) {
        // Do something about the error.
 }
    A more complex query, where there are multiple results, and multiple WHERE clauses, and the data should be ordered by a column:

    "SELECT column FROM table WHERE value1=a AND value2=b ORDER BY value3"
     try{
 
        ArrayList<> results = dbTwo.getOrderedStringArrayWithQuery("table", "column",
                                                                        "value1=? AND value2=?", new String[] { "a", "b" }, "value3");
 
 } catch (DataNotFoundException dnfe) {
        // Do something about the error.
 }
    Version:
    0.1
    Author:
    Michael Clarke

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static SAWDatabaseHelper getInstance(Context context,
                            java.lang.String dbName)
        Used to load a new database instance. Example usage, assuming you have two databases in the /assets folder of your project: /assets/mydatabase.sqlite /assets/myotherdatabase.sqlite SAWDatabaseHelper dbOne = SAWDatabaseHelper.getInstance( getApplicationContext(), "mydatabase"); SAWDatabaseHelper dbTwo = SAWDatabaseHelper.getInstance( getApplicationContext(), "myotherdatabase");
        Parameters:
        dbName - The file name of the .sqlite file in the "assets" folder.
        context - The application or activity/fragment context.
        Returns:
        The existing database instance if one already exists for the given database, otherwise a new instance for the given .sqlite database.

      • getStringWithQuery

        public java.lang.String getStringWithQuery(java.lang.String tableName,
                                  java.lang.String columnName,
                                  java.lang.String where,
                                  java.lang.String[] whereArgs)
                                    throws DataNotFoundException
        This method is used to get a string from the database.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table in the database that holds the string we're after.
        columnName - The column name we're after.
        where - Any WHERE clauses, i.e. "id=? AND name=?, etc."
        whereArgs - The arguments that match the WHERE clause, in a String array.
        Returns:
        The found string, if it is in the database.
        Throws:
        DataNotFoundException - if the data if not in the database, or if an error occurs.

      • getCharWithQuery

        public char getCharWithQuery(java.lang.String tableName,
                    java.lang.String columnName,
                    java.lang.String where,
                    java.lang.String[] whereArgs)
                      throws DataNotFoundException
        This method is used to get a single character from the SQLite database. It can also be used to get just the first character of a string entry in the database.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table in the database that holds the character we're after.
        columnName - The column name we're after.
        where - Any WHERE clauses, i.e. "id=? AND name=?, etc."
        whereArgs - The arguments that match the WHERE clause, in a String array.
        Returns:
        The found character, if it is in the database.
        Throws:
        DataNotFoundException - if the data if not in the database, or if an error occurs.

                        throws DataNotFoundException
        This method is used to get an integer from the SQLite database.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table in the database that holds the integer value we're after.
        columnName - The column name we're after.
        where - Any WHERE clauses, i.e. "id=? AND name=?, etc."
        whereArgs - The arguments that match the WHERE clause, in a String array.
        Returns:
        The found integer, if it is in the database.
        Throws:
        DataNotFoundException - if the data if not in the database, or if an error occurs.

      • getCountWithQuery

        public int getCountWithQuery(java.lang.String tableName,
                    java.lang.String columnName,
                    java.lang.String where,
                    java.lang.String[] whereArgs)
                      throws DataNotFoundException
        This method is used to the a count of the number of items matching the requested query string.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table name in the database to query.
        columnName - The column name in the table that holds the data we want.
        where - Any specific constraints, i.e. "id=?", otherwise null.
        whereArgs - The argument strings that match the "where" param, otherwise null.
        Returns:
        An integer with the number of items that matched the search criteria.
        Throws:
        DataNotFoundException - If no data is found, we throw this.

        DataNotFoundException - If no data is found, we throw this.

      • getOrderedStringArrayWithQuery

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> getOrderedStringArrayWithQuery(java.lang.String tableName,
                                                                   java.lang.String columnName,
                                                                   java.lang.String where,
                                                                   java.lang.String[] whereArgs,
                                                                   java.lang.String orderBy)
                                                                     throws DataNotFoundException
        This method is used to get a whole array of string values from the database. The array will be ordered by the orderBy value.
        Parameters:
        tableName - The table name in the database to query.
        columnName - The column name in the table that holds the data we want.
        where - Any specific constraints, i.e. "id=?", otherwise null.
        whereArgs - The argument strings that match the "where" param, otherwise null.
        orderBy - The column to order values by.
        Returns:
        An array list of strings that match the requested criteria.
        Throws:
        DataNotFoundException - If no data is found, we throw this.
